stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the platforming layout for a new ice level (Course 13), tested it on N64 hardware where he discovered a major camera bug, and discussed his development philosophies. He also hosted and provided live commentary for the F3 fan game expo.

development_findings.summary: The project is nearing completion, with only two levels remaining to be built after the current one (Course 13) is finished.

Testing on N64 hardware revealed a major camera/frame buffer glitch in a large area. Kaze's immediate fix is to shrink the level, but he acknowledges a more complex, inventive technical solution may be required.
development_findings.quote: I think this level is a little too big and that's why the camera does this. It usually does that when you have a really big area. I might have to invent a solution to that problem.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has implemented an 'infinite render distance' feature in the 'Bunny Brush' level, which functions even on original N64 hardware.
The game now includes a toggle for anti-aliasing, allowing players to choose their preferred visual style.
Kaze has a highly streamlined workflow that allows him to push a new build of the game to a real N64 for testing with a single button press.
Kaze encountered a technical limitation with a pre-existing texture combiner for snow effects and decided he would need to create a new one from scratch to achieve his desired look.
development_findings.quote: This snow combiner is way too messed up to work with. I'm gonna have to make up something new.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is currently developing Course 13, a surreal, icy castle level that will end in a large treasure room.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes mainstream games for popular franchises must be 'bland' to ensure sales, while ROM hacks are free from commercial pressure, allowing for more creativity.
context_findings.quote: When you have to sell well, you have to make something somewhat bland. And ROM hacks don't have to sell well. So ROM hacks can get a little more creative.

context_findings.summary: Kaze strongly disagrees with the idea that fan game creators should hide their work to avoid CNDs, arguing that secrecy is self-defeating and that public showcases like F3 are beneficial.
context_findings.quote: If you make a fan game and you shut up about it and you don't show anyone, you CND'd yourself. Why are you doing Nintendo's job for them?

context_findings.summary: Kaze's artistic philosophy is to focus on evoking a specific feeling for the player, rather than adhering to traditional art principles which he feels are for critics.
context_findings.quote: You don't want to operate on principles because if you operate on principles, you make art for critics, you don't make art for the sake of it being experienced.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's daughter was born five days prior to the stream. He jokes that his identity as an artist makes him more proud of his creative work than his child.
context_findings.quote: Somehow I'm more proud of this than of the child. What can I say? I'm an artist.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to create and sell a physical box and instruction booklet for the game, without any Nintendo branding, as a souvenir for players. He anticipates that others will illegally produce cartridges to complete the set.
He has a video idea titled 'How Nintendo's optimizations in Mario 64 made the game run worse,' suggesting he has found multiple instances where Nintendo's code was counterproductive to performance.

Kaze's strategy for YouTube content is to embed game progress previews within technical videos, as he believes viewers prefer technical content over direct spoilers but he still needs to show progress on the hack.

biobak.summary: Biobak designed and modeled the updated 'Fuzzy' enemies, now depicted with protective gear.
biobak.quote: This was Biobak's idea and Biobak made the model. They're now wearing protective gear.

biobak.summary: When a viewer praised the game's art and color palettes, Kaze suggested the viewer might appreciate Biobak's contributions more than his own, highlighting Biobak's key role in the game's visual identity.

zeina.summary: Zeina is currently caring for their newborn daughter, Reyna, with help from her mother.
Kaze acknowledges that the work of caring for their newborn is likely falling more heavily on Zeina at the moment.
zeina.quote: It doesn't feel like that much [work], although it's probably a lot more work for Zeina than for me.

key_stories.title: The N64 Camera Bug
key_stories.summary: While testing on a real N64, Kaze discovered a major camera bug in a large level. He immediately diagnosed the cause and implemented a short-term design fix by shrinking the area, while noting a more robust technical solution might be needed later.
key_stories.challenge: A large area in the new ice level caused a severe graphical glitch on real N64 hardware where the screen would smear because the frame buffer wasn't clearing.
key_stories.process: Kaze tested the level on his N64 via his capture card, observed the bug, immediately diagnosed the cause as the area's size, and decided on a two-tiered solution: one immediate (design) and one potential (programming).
key_stories.outcome: As a temporary fix, Kaze decided to shrink the level's geometry to prevent the bug. He acknowledged that a proper, more complex technical fix might be needed in the future to support such large areas.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this level is a little too big and that's why the camera does this... I might have to invent a solution to that problem.

key_stories.title: The 'Don't CND Yourself' Philosophy
key_stories.summary: Kaze pushed back against the common fan-game development wisdom of staying silent to avoid legal trouble. He argued that this approach is self-defeating and that public events like F3 are essential for the community, having run for years without issue.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze feels there is a pervasive, fearful mindset in the modding community that creators must hide their projects to avoid getting a Cease and Desist (CND) from companies like Nintendo.
key_stories.process: In response to a viewer comment and as host of the F3 event, Kaze articulated his philosophy, blaming another (unnamed) YouTuber for spreading the fear and arguing that silence is more harmful to a project than publicity.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze actively uses his platform to argue against this secrecy, promoting public development and events like F3 as a way to build community and market projects, believing the risk of a CND is overblown.
key_stories.key_quote: If you make a fan game and you shut up about it and you don't show anyone, you CND'd yourself. Why are you doing Nintendo's job for them?

key_stories.title: Art for Feeling, Not for Critics
key_stories.summary: When asked about his design skills, Kaze detailed his core artistic philosophy. He rejects creating art based on established principles, which he feels is for critics, and instead focuses on using his tools to evoke a specific feeling for the player.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer asked Kaze to explain the source of his artistic skill in level design and color theory.
key_stories.process: Instead of listing schools or formal training, Kaze explained his abstract, feeling-based approach. He contrasted his method with a principles-based one, which he dismissed as being for critics and prone to becoming outdated.
key_stories.outcome: This exchange revealed a core tenet of Kaze's creative identity: he prioritizes the player's feeling and experience over academic principles, which he believes results in more unique and engaging art.
key_stories.key_quote: You don't want to operate on principles because if you operate on principles, you make art for critics, you don't make art for the sake of it being experienced.
